text: all right so we are going to talk a bit about using AWS and open data to meet demands of disaster response situations
so I'm gonna lead off with a little bit of an overview of some of the things that I've been thinking about recently
along these lines and I'm gonna bring up Tyler right Radford who's the executive director with humanitarian OpenStreetMap
team so if you were in our first session around transportation you would have seen OpenStreetMap come up there and
then it'll come up again here today so I think one of the first things I want to start about is open data is in the
session title so what what why do we care about open data I think this is one
of the most common questions that we get a lot when we go around and talk about open data and I think it's easy for from
our perspective but we care about it because our customers care about it right so we have a large number of generally public sector customers who
are looking to make a lot of data available in the cloud in efficient and optimized manners and the reason that
they're looking to do that is because we have a large number of customers on the other side on the demand side who are looking to use that data in the cloud
and if you were just in here for the excellent previous talk that was generally about how to make at why
they're making their data available in the cloud for their customers to use when you can do the processing next to
the data sitting in the cloud it's a much better process for everyone both on the supply side and the demand side so
we look to figure out best practices in a number of ways and we have a public
data sets program that we run through the open data team and we make a number of datasets available here I mean
generally when we think about this we think to ourselves we're trying to make the most the more data more available to
more people so you can see the more about the open data program there if you're looking for particular datasets
we launched the registry of open data on AWS about a month or two ago and you can find not only the datasets that we've
sort of curated and work closely with a number of our customers to make available but also datasets that other
groups are making available themselves in the cloud on AWS and so these are groups who have a mission or mandate to
make their data available and then they themselves can go and register their datasets there so it's a good place for
you to go look if you're looking for data sources to use but also if you were looking to make your data more widely available you
can go here and self register we also have the earth on AWS initiative which
is the way that we try and coalesce all our geospatial data sets and activities in one place so it makes it easier for
you all to go and see what is available and so if you go here you will see a
number of our large geospatial data sets that we make available in the cloud like Landsat Sentinel 2 Sentinel 1 modis data
MAPE USDA aerial imagery 1 meter imagery data sets like OpenStreetMap and so one
of the things that I thought about and I think this is actually during the holidays two years ago now sort of had
some free time and I wanted to think of how to to bring some of this together together in a prototype in a meaning
meaningful fashion right because I sit on the team that has access to sort of this 10 petabytes of freely available
data a lot of it very useful geospatial data but it still takes there needs to
be a piece to make it useful for people right and so I sort of came up with this idea of I wanted to bring some prototype
together that would provide meaningful actionable information as quickly as possible to respond to disaster
situations arising from earthquakes right and as an aside for any of you sitting in the back of the room I don't know if it's the same in the front there
is some like there's like a very weird vibration going on in the back of the room I don't know if there's traffic
nearest but it feels a little bit like an earthquake so it's very very interesting just so for all you people
in the back so what is this that I sort of had in mind I just wanted to be able to get data to
sort of first responders as quickly as possible right and so I sort of thought about a
blueprint of what this would look like and I'm just gonna step through a number of these little segments here and so
first of all if you if you're looking at the the diagram that you see here for those of you who are familiar with AWS
and step functions you will notice that this is just a step functions outline so step step functions is a service that
basically lets you set a programmatic blueprint to fire off different functions and it can
handle failures and retries and logic like if else's or weights or parallel
states and so all of these things will fire off in the the manner that I set them to do and so the trigger for this
step function is coming from the USGS Earthquake feed so there's currently an RSS feed which is something that I set
up a mechanism to poll I used a lambda function to pull this RSS feed and turn it into an SNS feed which is something
that we use in AWS to trigger things programmatically so there can be any number of listeners to this SNS feed and
so what I did was say anytime that there's a new earthquake that happens around the world I will run the step
function right and so what does this step function do so we'll start we'll start walking through some of the steps
of this step function so the first thing that it does is it checks magnitude again keep in mind this is all a simple
prototype this isn't like a well baked solution that I'm trying to get anyone to actually use it's just sort of a way for me to think
about how the various open datasets and services that we offer can be used in a disaster response situation so the first
thing I do is I check magnitude I say if it's above a 5.0 then start doing something if it's below a 5.0 it's not
of interest right and so just and the step function is done and remember this happens within seconds of the data being
made available through the USGS earthquake feed so the first thing we do is we start collecting imagery from open
sources right and so as I mentioned through the earth on AWS initiative we've got data like Sentinel 2 which is
optical data Sentinel one which is SAR data Landsat which is also optical data and
they're all sitting there and there's sort of multi petabyte catalogs but we
don't need all of that data right we only need a small piece of it and so if some of you saw eliminate ephors talk at
the Earth and space event they started talking about these sort of archives of convenience you could think of this as a similar thing which is what we do is we
say if it's above a magnitude 5.0 earthquake I will grab the imagery over the epicenter I will grab the latest
three somewhat cloud-free scenes and this is actually I'm literally waving my hands now because you could set up this
logic to be whatever you wanted so I think I said give me the last three images with the cloud cover under 20%
and I will copy them over from the archive and stick them in an archive of convenience to borrow a term and it is
in a bucket that is ready for you to use immediately that you can share with anyone right it's publicly available it
was already publicly available data but now it is publicly available in a smaller scale just those images that you
need so again within seconds you now have access to all the pre-event imagery
that you could want from a number of these open sources there's nothing that would prevent you from doing this with
say high-resolution commercial imagery sources that would just be a different chunk of code and of course for the
prototype I didn't put that in so what can you do once you have that imagery available well there's a lot you can do
with it if you're making the imagery smartly available in a number of formats cloud optimized formats this here is
working on top of something called cloud optimized YouTube but there's a number of cloud optimized formats and what you're seeing here is a tile server and
so this is a slippy map if you're used to the web development world it's just a map that you can move around and you
start to see the imagery tiles coming in and keep in mind this could be sort of lower resolution data or moderate
resolution data or it could also be high resolution data so you can see exactly what's going on in the ground but the
thing to remember here is that this is actually running in a server list fashion so if there's no disaster if
there's nothing in this bucket and nobody's using it it doesn't cost anything so it's only when you start
making web requests to power your your interface your browser UI and you start making the requests to get this data
that's when you start paying but as soon as you're done pre or post disaster there's no cost for any of this right so
it's basically a service just like all of our services that you only you only pay for once you start using it but you
can use this for more than just visualization you can also use it for analysis so this is work from synergize
that they've done doing analysis Greg I know you're here in the audience I think this is Sentinel - most likely ok he
gave a nod good so this is using server list functionality to do analysis on the
data right and so again the type of analysis doesn't really matter this is just sort of throwing out some ideas but
the same thing applies here you make the data smartly available in the cloud you can use functionality and
functions that only spin up when you start making the requests to allow you to do on-the-fly analysis so you didn't
have to go through a lengthy process of pre-processing anything or caching anything you can do this all on the fly
within seconds of the disaster striking so something that we're gonna talk about
that came up in an earlier session I mentioned OpenStreetMap OpenStreetMap is a base map of the world so it's building
footprints roads points of interests one thing that you might want to do around an epicenter is say where are all the
hospitals so this comes from work that Seth Fitzsimmons did around getting the OpenStreetMap data into the a but AWS
public datasets program it was made available in a columnar format so that it's very easily queryable and so you
can programmatically or you could write by hand a query like this that says give me all the hospitals
around Guinea Sierra Leone and Liberia or you could just do it around an epicenter obviously and so from the
earthquake feed we know where the earthquake is happening and then again within seconds we can say here are all
the hospitals within a hundred kilometer radius and depending on how the data is tagged you can also say these are their
qualities or these are the sort of facilities that they have available and then of course you could also do something like programmatically start
sending them notices to be on alert so all of and sort of anything is possible
again right waving waving my hands a lot here and I think the other important thing to notice is that and this might
come up when Tyler talks in a bit is that with OpenStreetMap we don't own that map the community owns that map
right and so you could imagine efforts and there are a number of groups that do this you could imagine efforts that if
you're looking at disaster prone areas you can have groups go in and pre update
the map right so that the map is in the best possible position for when a disaster strikes because obviously you
can query the map and get all the data you want but if it's not up-to-date it's not helpful right in fact it's probably even worse than not helpful
so this is just another example here this is looking at building quality so again you can look around the epicenter
you could look at the building quality to get an idea of what state the buildings were in pre events and this
could be useful as a metric to wonder how many buildings might have been most affected by the events right so
obviously if the building structure isn't a very good quality you might say okay this isn't maybe one of our initial targets to look at for further study and
again all that data is it with in OpenStreetMap so you could also run
machine learning data is on the model sorry machine learning models on the data this was definitely something I
wanted to do but it did not happen so what I'm going to do instead is talk a little bit about other groups that are
using AWS to sort of promote the state-of-the-art with machine learning around this sort of imagery right and so
this is a group called space net it's a collaboration between cosmic works radiant solutions and NVIDIA and it's a
machine learning corpus of aerial imagery so currently it's just satellite imagery but you could imagine aerial
imagery drone imagery so clean imagery drone imagery could also go in here they also run challenges around the data to
get people to open-source their algorithms for better machine learning
purposes right so they're trying to get groups to open up with algorithms to better detect buildings roads points of
interest to date they've given out a little over a hundred thousand dollars in cash prizes to incentivize people to
work on this this data is all available on s3 the newest challenge that's coming up if you're familiar satellite imagery
a lot of it's taken straight down they're gonna see how far off straight down you can take the imagery and still
have your machine learning models work because the idea is if you don't need an image that's straight down in a disaster
response situation you can probably get an image much quicker because you don't have to wait for the satellite to be directly overhead and so if your machine
learning models work when your image doesn't need to be straight down and then you get imagery much quicker and start to respond much more quickly
there's also work from groups like development seed who are doing open source work to do a number of the same
sort of same sort of analyses one other thing that's very interesting
remember AWS has a broad breadth of services so I just kind of threw this one in here because I think it's fascinating and we actually did this
with American Red Cross you could in an automated fashion spin up a call center so one of the things that starts
happening around disasters is people start calling the phone lines and they generally don't have the capacity to handle that so with the American Red
Cross we actually spun up using a service called Amazon connect we spun up a call center we actually volunteered to
staff the phone lines in that scenario you can use technology to do this you can use things like lambda functions to
provide voice interfaces but we volunteered and provided people on the lines but then once the disaster is done
the call center goes away and you're not paying for it anymore right and again all of this stuff can be done in an
automated fashion but you there's probably a lot of things that you could do that you don't want done in an automated fashion so step functions also
allows you to basically put a human in the loop so if there are certain processes like if you're doing a
large-scale people the deployment you probably want somebody in the loop to
say yes we should deploy people or no we should not deploy people and you can also put these into your step functions
as well so this the the sort of last thing I want to talk about was actually
something that we have a demo of up in the expo hall we worked with a drone deploying humanitarian OpenStreetMap
team to sort of put this prototype in the demo together is you can deploy sort
of a little mobile the response Center
into the field right so we have something called a snowball edge which is around a it's a hundred terabytes of storage with
compute onboard it's a hard encase it just runs off of normal power I'm sure you could run it off a generator but
it's raining dust resistant and so what you can do with this is actually run an
interface off of it to display satellite imagery drone imagery that's coming in
you could have pre event data that's loaded onto the box when it leaves one of our facilities because remember a lot
of our customers or maybe put this the other way a lot of the groups that are flying high-resolution satellites are
our customers a lot of the groups that have sort of globally spanning large satellite imagery datasets our customer
so a lot of that data is already sitting in s3 and so you can ship one of these from one of our regions and they can go
out with up to a hundred terabytes of data already on them so this isn't data you need to access in the field this
device can be shipped to the field with the data already on it and then if you're doing drone over flights in the field that data can go
right down to the box you can use something like open aerial map to act as an interface to look at that data in a
cohesive manner you can use something like Portable Open Street Map to do field enumeration so you can do wellness
checks right you can update the map on the fly and then that can be put back into the system so when you need to
route people for first response situations they can be routed using the most up-to-date data that you have
available because you have people on the ground updating it without any external network connectivity and it can go right
back to the box so here's an example of the drone imagery coming in we can see
using open aerial map as an interface for looking at the data side by side this is pre and post from the Hawaiian
Volcano that's going on you can use tools like QGIS right so you can use
local sort of laptop desktop analytic software in the field running off the
snowball edge and like I said you can use portable OpenStreetMap possum to update the maps
in the field you can use something like open data kit for field enumeration wellness checks that will also go back
to the snowball edge and then you can reroute based on that and finally once
you collect all this data you can have that sent back to our data centers where it'll end up in an s3 bucket so that
this data isn't stuck on the device the device is initially intended as an import or export device so you can use
it in the field and you can use a cluster of them as well they're not stuck to just being single ones and then you can ship them back to our facilities
and they will end up in an s3 bucket of your choosing so if you're interested in seeing any
more of these pieces there's some links up there there's another talk this afternoon around a similar concept

about the work that humanitarian OpenStreetMap team is doing thank you
thank you very good morning to everyone I'm really

world and they're doing this and being powered through AWS solutions and I'll
tell you a little bit more about that let's see if I can move over here so the
story starts with some not-so-great news back in 2010 the earthquake in Haiti
which many of you will will remember and affected hundreds of thousands of people
and many tens of thousands or possibly hundreds of thousands of people lost

that's the earthquake taking place and you see as you see these little flashes of light these are not aftershocks these
are actually volunteers all around the world who are creating an open map of
Haiti using OpenStreetMap and each of those flashes is an individual edit to the map that a volunteer is making so
what did we end up with on the on the left here you're seeing the map in the surrounding area around port-au-prince
before the earthquake take took place and then on the right side you're seeing what the map looked like in the
incredible detail that was filled in by hundreds of volunteers who came together online using OpenStreetMap this is just
eighteen days later and this map had been provided in the preceding weeks directly to responders on the ground so

mentioned this these volunteers were coming together using OpenStreetMap which is sort of the world's largest
open geospatial volunteer project where people are working together to create
super detailed maps of every location in the world one of the challenges we saw
after the earthquake in Haiti is that many people they jumped online they wanted to help but people were working
in the same areas in editing the map in the same area so we had this idea we need some sort of a coordination tool
and that's what you're seeing on the screen here is that we created a product called tasking manager which basically
just gridded out the map and it allowed each volunteer to work on a discrete section of that map
so what happens this is a little bit kind of a look into the process a volunteer is presented with satellite
imagery sitting at their laptop they essentially trace over what they see so
the buildings in the roads so they essentially digitized from a satellite image and let me just go back here yeah
and so what you end up with is sort of vector data that then you can analyze you can use in GPS devices for
navigation you can print out the challenge we have today is that we're
still facing the Haiti 2010 issue in 2018 in many places around the world if
you open them up on your whatever map app you use on your phone you'll see that there's in rural areas there's
often just big big empty spaces big areas of gray or tan depending on what
map you're using and these are often the places most vulnerable to disaster so why do why do maps why do we care why do
maps even matter during disaster well they help us answer some of the most basic questions things like what area
was affected who what supplies are needed who's most at need and it helps
us get the right people and right supplies to the right place at the right time so the maps that are generated by
volunteers are directly used by responders such as Doctors Without Borders or or the Red Cross on the
ground as they're providing relief and this is all happening through the OpenStreetMap project so what is hard so
my organization is called humanitarian OpenStreetMap team h.o.t and and we work
to coordinate this global effort of volunteers around OpenStreetMap so so far since the earthquake in Haiti we've
had 100,000 volunteers work with us over the years and they represent not just people here in the United States not
just in DC these are people all around the world who are contributing from their countries helping people affected
by disaster in in the same country or in other countries so since 2010 hot has
used this tasking manager tool to coordinate the volunteer effort and more than 50 rapid responses and you can see

and several other several of their ongoing events so this is what the

so that when our tasking manager is hit by hundreds or thousands of volunteers
